segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 The main point of this talk is about corporate red teaming.
Those of you who were here yesterday would have heard Justin talking about outsourced
red teaming, where it's really important to test certain things, to check certain check
boxes or flags that a customer is after.
I think corporate red teaming can expand a little bit on that.
So a couple of questions first.
Hands up if you lead a red team.
Good job.
Okay.
Hands up if you're in a red team.
We're lucky, red team people.
Put your hands up if you want to lead a red team.
Okay.
Cool.
So, this talk is really based on my own experience, as well as, I guess, a lot of what I call
benchmarking.
So over the years, had many discussions with other red teams at various different industries.
But all of this, I guess, is my own opinion, and I'm very opinionated.
So feel free to disagree or agree, and we can discuss that later.
Also, if you're someone that likes to take notes, don't worry too much.
There's, like, 30 pages of appendix with loads of different bullets, you know, def by PowerPoint
as well, with a lot of little hints and tips that might be of use.
So we'll start off with, I guess, benchmarking what is red teaming.
So red teaming, to me, is a group of independent people from a diverse background, various
different skills, different ways of thinking, different opinions.
And they're trying to use this experience to solve problems, to give a different perspective.
And, of course, the most important thing is that we're trying to simulate or replicate
those activities of a real-world adversary of some sort.
I think red teaming is threat-centric, not vulnerability-centric.
So it's not about running scanners and giving a report and all sorts of different things.
And I think that's one of the biggest problems we have in our industry, is we have no commonality
of all these different things, right?
So someone will tell you they do red teaming.
In my opinion, it won't be red teaming.
They'll just run Qualys or something.
Perhaps they're a penetration testing team, all different things.
So really, I want to kind of try and forget about colors a little bit.
I know this is a red and blue conference.
But just talk about the adversary and emulating that.
So I want to start off by saying red is not best.
So lots of people will say, I want to be on a red team because it's an elite thing and it's marvelous.
Red is just different, right?
So if you think about security as a puzzle, red teaming is just another piece in that puzzle.
It's not a substitute or a replacement for anything else.
And we get this quite a lot when interviewing people.
They want to be on a red team because they want to fuck shit up, right?
That's what they say.
And perhaps they're really awesome at doing that, but they might be better off at a very focused
penetration testing team role, right?
Because that's where their skills and experiences is more beneficial.
So we shouldn't be doing red teaming instead of or a substitution to anything else.
This is really complimentary.
And I think it's important to keep that in mind as we go through this, right?
So in my mind, red teaming shouldn't be trying to replicate or duplicate something else.
It's bringing a different perspective, a different vision to bring different learnings
and outcomes for that organization.
So the reason for this talk is I think rarely do we ever discuss kind of what's involved
in setting up a red team.
So lots of people I speak to who are in the red team, I say,
well, how did your red team come to exist?
Well, we used to be the pen test team, and now red teaming is the really cool thing.
So now we're called the red team.
Or we used to do vulnerability scanning, and now we do this.
Or someone needed a red team set up due to some reason, so that's why we're called the red team.
There's no real necessary reason why it is really a red team other than people like colors.
And I think we need to challenge ourselves to do better.
I think as leaders, we need to challenge ourselves to do better.
And as you, as people in a red team, need to expect more from each other and from your leaders.
So this is really hoping for you to go back to your companies and give your boss a hard time
and say we should be doing this shit better or different or being inspired hopefully to do it yourself better.
So I really want to draw some change.
And like I said, I'm really frustrated with all this color crap.
So it's not red teaming, it's black teaming because you do physical stuff.
And it's purple teaming because it's red team and blue team.
Let's just do awesome, amazing stuff and not worry about adding another color or another brand,
which just confuses things even more.
So I tried to break down this journey of kind of building an adversarial capability into a few stages.
So you've got strategy, buy-in, process, resources, people.
I know it's terrible to call people resources, but it's not just people.
It's hardware and software as well.
Then obviously the execution and then collaboration.
So we're trying to go through these different stages and kind of give you some insight and think what's required.
So I don't think you can do any of this unless you start from a strong foundation.
So depending on what you're doing already, you may be at different stages.
So I try and think of this as like a crawl, walk, run, fly type situation.
So perhaps you're already in a red team and you're at a certain stage and you think you can't go any further.
You can continue to push the boundaries.
So really the first thing you need to understand is what is the business mission?
So what is it that you as a red team are here to try and help this organization do?
And really for me, the whole idea of a red team is you're enabling the business to make more informed risk decisions.
But you can't help them do that unless you understand what it is that they're trying to do.
And you've got to be pragmatic with what you're doing.
So you really need to understand who those key stakeholders are that are going to enable you to do this.
So a key thing about red team is trust.
So I think if you're doing this properly, it should be against live production environments.
There shouldn't be scope. There should be minimal restrictions to some extent.
Obviously we don't want to bring everything down.
But that means you're going to have to get the buy-in from those certain people at the top.
And that's not going to happen if you're just getting approved from someone
who also doesn't have the courage to push harder to do more.
And don't be defined by what everyone else is doing.
Or if the organization you're at has never done this before.
Or other teams have tried to do this, but they can't do it.
Our job is to push harder to do better.
And we're never going to push the boundaries of what we're doing as red teams unless we continue to put up a fight.
And a key part of this is going to be to enable trust.
So lots of organizations I talk to that still say they do red teaming, they're never doing it in production.
Or they're only doing it in, it's definitely production, but it isn't.
Or we can only do it in production, but at least certain hours.
And I understand the reasons for all this stuff.
But I'm sure most of you can say from experience that a dev or test environment is never the same as production.
If anything, there's never the same detection controls in those environments.
So part of what you're trying to test with this approach is the ability to protect, detect, and respond.
So how can you do that effectively?
I think it's the guy yesterday who was talking about the target.
Where you've got to go around and find certain people that you're going to socially engineer.
I understand the rationale for that, but the adversary doesn't deal with any of that crap, right?
So we have to manage to be able to do as close as we can and stimulate what the adversary is doing.
But with control and making sure that we don't proper screw up.
Because then we've got problems.
And like I said at the bottom there, failure to plan, you're just basically planning to fail.
So you need to get a strong foundation, you need to get the right buy-in, you need to get the right support.
You need to get the budgets and everything sorted out or you're not going to get anywhere.
So buy-in being the next stage.
So you've got this plan, you understand what you think red teaming is.
You think you understand what it is the business is trying to do and what benefit you're going to bring.
Now you've got to try and sell that to the right people, right?
So hopefully you can get it at sea level, so at the board.
So basically they're the people, the accountable people that if you screw up, they're the people that are in trouble, right?
So if you bring down the infrastructure at a retail organization or a financial institution, wherever it may be.
They're the people who are asked, you want your ass covered by those people, right?
Not someone who's not the accountable person.
So you really want that support and buy-in.
You're going to need things that people don't always think about.
Obviously financial support makes sense because you need people to be a red team.
You need software, you need infrastructure, all these things make sense.
But lots of the times, if you're doing this in the way I think is right, you're going to be breaching all your company's policies every day, right?
Because you're not supposed to break stuff.
You're not supposed to impersonate people.
You're not supposed to do any of this sort of thing.
So you need to make sure you spend a lot of time understanding the stakeholders.
Who in HR do you need to speak to?
Is it privacy people?
Are there compliance people?
All these different people to get the approvals of how you're going to operate.
Speak to legal and say, right, we're going to look at impersonating organizations when we're doing social engineering.
Are you comfortable with that?
What's the impact?
We're going to be socially engineering any member of the company, including the CEO and the CISO and the financial director and all these people.
How does that work?
What sign-off do we need?
What kind of mitigating controls do we have to have in place?
What information are we going to share?
All these things are really important.
You just can't do it effectively.
That also comes down to the rules of engagement.
When you're doing this, who are you going to notify?
When are you going to notify them?
How long is it going to happen?
Again, I think you obviously need permission.
Because, again, you need your ask coverage.
You're going to be doing this for a certain period of time.
Who is going to be aware that it's happening?
I think you should only have, ideally, no more than a dozen, if possible, people in the company.
If it's a large organization, of course.
If it's smaller, it should be less.
Because you want to make sure that when you're doing this, it really is for real.
Only a minimal amount of people know that it's happening.
They respond to it in that way.
The devil is in the detail.
We got to this stage where we understand why we're doing what it is.
We've hopefully got the buy-in and started to establish some trust with people.
Now, it's time to see if we can document all this stuff.
We all love documentation, but it's important to cover our ass.
You want to understand what is your operating model.
When you do physical engagements, for example, are you going to break windows and smash doors?
Is that not possible?
Can you do lock-picking and bumping?
That's not possible?
What can you do?
Can you drive a truck through the door?
All these things might seem obvious or stupid questions at the same time.
Some people are going to let you smash doors, hire trucks, and drive through doors.
If that's what their risk appetite is.
You want to have this all documented.
Get them signed off by the legal team, the privacy teams, the HR teams, all this stuff.
Ultimately, someone's going to ask you that question.
What were you doing going in someone's bag, stealing their badge?
It was in our operating procedure.
It was signed off.
You need to have your ass covered.
That comes back to the statement of work as well.
Every time you do something, like I said, we're breaking the company's policies, most likely, in what we're doing.
The statement of work should define, at a higher level, what is the objective that you're trying to achieve?
When are you doing it?
Who are the signatories?
Who are the people that are signing off?
Based on experience, it can be really hard to get these things signed off in a timely manner.
When you're doing this from the beginning, you want to try and get things pre-approved.
You're almost asking forgiveness and hoping that people read the email.
If they don't respond within a certain period of time, then that is your approval.
I think that's one of the hardest things that people seem to get.
When I speak to different red teams about how many red team assessments they do in a year,
you've got the two schools of thought.
Some say they do 50 red team assessments a year.
These are the ones that, in my opinion, aren't necessarily really red teaming.
It's like a one-week engagement, including reporting everything.
Then you've got the other ones that say, we only do about three,
because it's really hard to get the different sign-offs for the people to do all the things.
Somehow you need to find some middle ground.
I think Rob covered some of this in his talk yesterday.
You need to understand what it is you're reporting out on and what is the communication model.
When you've done this piece of work, how long until you're going to give them the output?
Whether that be a really lengthy report, are you going to present it,
or there's documentation of all the findings,
how are you going to do it, when are you going to do it,
and I think Rob mentioned this,
because you don't want people constantly interrupting what you're doing.
It's going to impact your thought process and your flow,
and actually how effective you are.
If you're doing this for six, eight, ten weeks,
or if you're doing it non-stop throughout the year,
you don't want to have to keep on downing tools every five days to give someone a debrief on,
I've been looking through shares for 500 hours.
It's really interesting, but really that's all I've been doing.
That is a reality, I think, a lot of time with red teaming.
It's not that sexy stuff.
The sexy stuff comes when you find that password in a clear text file,
and then it gives you access to all the things.
The other things, again, these are all boring things, but important things,
is how you're managing and auditing the tasks and the activities you do.
You're going to screw up, because you're humans, people make mistakes,
so you need to be able to quickly understand what happened,
who did it, where they did it, to help fix the problem.
But then more importantly, I think,
because I think most of the time you can be honest if you've screwed up, right,
and help fix things, but due to this type of work,
you're going to get blamed, probably, for issues and outages, right?
So then you need this material to, again, cover your ass,
to prove that we weren't on that system, we didn't execute these commands,
the activities that were taken had nothing to do with us.
I can speak from experience quite recently that this is very important.
Then we spoke, there's been a couple of talks
over the last couple of days on intelligence,
so I think intelligence is really important.
So we call ourselves an intelligence-led Red Team,
but I have opinions on that as well, of course.
So I think intelligence is really important.
You want to partner with either internal intelligence teams, if you have them,
or get intelligence from outside, if you have the funding or availability.
But I also don't think that you should be restricted
to just using that intelligence, right?
So we speak about adversarial emulation,
and of course we should be trying to emulate the TTPs of the adversary,
but I don't think we should be restricted to just those TTPs, right?
So I'll give you an example.
A couple of years back, we were doing engagement,
trying to gain access to customer information,
and the TTPs and, I guess, the modus operandi that we had,
this threat actor in particular,
never had any evidence of attacking databases directly
to get access to information.
They always went through the application or some other channel
to gain access to that data.
We couldn't find a way to get access to that data the same way,
but we did find a way to get DBA access
and just take the data direct from the database.
Then when it came to reporting that out,
we had lots of interesting discussions with the intelligence team,
saying, well, that's not how that threat actor operates.
They don't take the data like that,
so we don't think this information is really helpful.
Lots of interesting discussion and debate.
Then two weeks later, I had a phone call
from that intelligence team to say, guess what?
We've just seen this threat actor
that you guys were emulating a few weeks ago,
and they've been stealing information direct from database.
So it's like, wow, imagine that.
So I think this is important because,
really, if we're doing this right,
I think we should really be doing anything
within our capabilities and our budget,
or whatever it may be,
to find the way of achieving those objectives by any means possible.
Because the adversary is going to be doing that, right?
If there's going to be a billion-pound paycheck at the end of it,
they're not going to go, oh, well, we normally go that way,
but we're not going to just utilize this other opportunity we've discovered.
They're going to constantly adapt.
It's really about being effective over sophistication, right?
So that comes back to my point
that I was kind of asking Justin about yesterday,
was why are you going to export something if you don't need to, right?
If someone's just left something open on the Internet,
you're not going to say, oh, well, I can't use that
because normally I need to export something
because that just doesn't make any sense.
And I think the key thing with all this stuff,
documentation is important,
and we can use checklists to actually make our job easier.
So a lot of the time, if we talk about checklists,
people kind of might interpret that
as we're taking their skill set away,
we're taking their decisions away.
But actually, I think it's the opposite, right?
So if you read books on some of the really smart people over time,
you'll read about decision fatigue, right?
So we've only got a certain amount of decisions
that we can make in a day before our brain kind of doesn't work right.
That's why Steve Jobs always wears the same clothes, right?
Because that's one decision he doesn't have to make every morning.
So if we document these things,
and we have checklists and procedures,
then we can really focus on using our brain
to make really educated decisions,
solving complex problems
when we're trying to simulate the adversary,
as opposed to just wondering
what was the right time to get the report in,
or what order should something be.
Okay, so then we come to resources.
So this isn't just about people,
but people are the most important thing of any red team.
So obviously, all the foundational stuff
you need to make things possible.
I want to speak to other red teams that have,
they say they have an internal red team,
but really they kind of outsource everything
and use third parties.
The number one reason why people say to me
they don't have an internal red team
is they don't think the work is challenging enough,
or the work isn't something that would retain that talent.
And I can agree.
So the leaders need to work harder, right?
To retain that talent,
make sure we're doing right things,
push the boundaries.
And kind of related to this foundational stuff
that I said in the first slide,
just because you can't do that in month one or year one
doesn't mean you don't keep on going back,
keep on changing the process, right?
So it's part of that crawl, walk, run, fly process.
You know, you're not going to,
well, at least it's very unlikely
that you're going to rock up to this company,
set up a red team, and say, right,
we're just going to be kind of hacking our ass
all day, every day,
without telling anyone from day one.
It's not going to happen, right?
You have to start off in small batches.
Perhaps it's just a two-week test,
and it's a six-week test,
and it's a 10-week test,
and then now you're into just doing it 24 by seven,
but perhaps that took you two, three, four, five years
to get there,
because the trust thing is really important.
When it comes to hiring,
I think team fit is really more important
than elite skills.
You can kind of teach kind of almost anyone anything,
but you can't stop an arsehole being an arsehole, right?
That's just how they are.
It's true.
We've tried.
It doesn't work.
You should also,
I should say I'm not hiring.
Everyone else is hiring.
I'm not hiring,
but when I'm hiring,
we do have remote people,
so I'm all favor for that.
I also think you should be hiring people better than you,
and also as much as you can better than everyone else
in the team.
Now, better doesn't mean some better skill.
It's all about different ways of thinking,
different ways of solving problems.
I think diversity is really important.
That also comes back to the remote thing, right?
So, the adversary is everywhere,
all over the place, right?
They're not all just sat in this one office
in London or Poland or wherever.
They're everywhere, right?
So, you want to have people that can reflect that.
So, you want people that can speak different languages,
people that have different backgrounds,
different cultures,
because they bring different ways of thinking, right?
That's what makes you an amazing team, right?
It's not a red person.
It's a red team.
So, you want diversification of thinking,
different ways of solving problems,
and I find this to be really, really helpful,
and I also think that, again, if it's a team effort,
obviously, it's difficult if you're building from scratch
because you tend to be just one person,
but you can ask friends for favors,
but try not to do this all in isolation, right?
So, you're building a team,
so those team of people should have a say
in who is going to be kind of brought in
to this, I guess, family, right?
That's the way I think about it,
but I will say,
I've learned this mistake a couple of times,
even though you want to, you know,
do this collaboratively,
trust your gut,
because the gut often doesn't lie,
and the few times that I've hired someone
that hasn't worked out very well,
I had a bad gut feeling,
and my gut was right,
and my brain was wrong,
but I'm learning,
so now, if the gut says no,
don't hire them.
And we really want people that solve problems, right?
So, less bitching, more doing.
So, we want people that,
when they find a problem,
they have the initiative
and the thought process
to solve a problem, right?
Red teaming is all about solving problems,
so the door is closed,
how do I get it open,
or how do I get around it, right?
So, we want people that solve problems
and come with solutions,
not just, this sucks,
or this is crap,
or I can't do this,
or I've got eight weeks
to try and break into here,
but it's really hard,
so I couldn't get past the door,
so I guess I give up, right?
Because if we were really the bad guys,
and our paycheck is behind that door,
you don't just kind of go,
sorry.
And I also think you should test people.
So, I know there's a few people here
that I've worked with before,
or I've been into at different places.
Test the people, right?
So, think about testing them technically,
but also socially.
So, again, someone could be
kind of mad skills on the keyboard, right?
But you can't talk to them,
they don't want to collaborate,
they're just going to sit on their own.
And again, there's nothing wrong with that,
but that might not be the best person
for a red team.
Perhaps they'd be better
in some sort of specialist
penetration testing role, right?
Where they can sit on their own
and not want to talk to anybody.
And I know in our industry,
we don't like to talk to people,
so that can be tricky.
And also, everyone can't think
like the bad guy, right?
So, when we hit these stumbling blocks,
we really should be trying to think about
doing things by almost any means possible, right?
And this is why it comes back
to that original foundational stage,
is can you only do technical stuff,
or can you do social stuff as well?
So, can you do social engineering,
so fishing, fishing, smishing,
all that sort of stuff?
Have you got physical capabilities as well?
If you don't have these options,
then you're already restricted.
And obviously, the bad guy
doesn't have those same restrictions.
And I think as leaders,
back to that original point
about people feel they can't retain staff,
we need to constantly find ways
to challenge and motivate people, right?
So, that's why I was asking
who's in a team,
and unfortunately,
there's not many red people here,
it would appear.
But perhaps if you do feel
that you're not challenged,
you're not motivated,
challenge your leaders
to give you more opportunities.
Again, be part of the solution,
don't just bitch that my job sucks
and everything's horrible here.
How can you make it better?
Come with options.
And also, I think all of us,
if we say not,
I think we're probably lying,
we all have egos,
because that's kind of why we do what we do.
But humility is really important, right?
Especially in a team,
I think it's important to understand
the benefit your co-workers bring.
So, they may not be able to
do exactly the same things as you,
but they're on that team
for a specific reason, right?
They have a skills or something
that they bring
that benefits overall.
Okay, so,
hopefully we've got
all the funding we need,
we can buy all the software,
all the hardware,
we've hired a ton of smart people
based all over the place,
and now it's time to actually
try and do this whole thing,
this whole adversarial emulation.
So, as I mentioned before,
we want to have some relationship
or some input
in terms of intelligence,
so we can understand
what it is that we're trying to emulate,
what's their motivation,
what kind of tools and tactics
and things are they using.
We really need to understand
what the scenario is.
So, I don't like to talk things
in terms of scoping,
because by scoping,
it sounds like there's stuff
that you can't do, right?
Now, we all know
there's always stuff that you can't do,
but I think in terms of framing something
in the terms of scoping,
you're already limiting yourself, right?
So, what is the scenario
and what are the objectives?
So, just to give an example,
I use this all the time.
So, someone comes to you and says,
we want a red team assessment.
We want you to red team our DLP solution.
Anyone have experience with that,
with that kind of scenario?
And the answer should be no,
because it's not a penetration testing team,
this is a red team.
So, again, not saying one's better
or the other,
this is just about a different perspective
of looking at it.
So, really, if you're doing
a red team engagement
and that is part of the scenario,
you need to take a step back, right?
So, the scenario should be understanding
why has that company put DLP in place?
Now, typically, it's to prevent
the loss of intellectual property
of some sort, right?
So, that intellectual property
should be the scenario objectives.
That's what you're trying to achieve, right?
So, as an adversary,
I don't think the adversary
is ever purposely trying to
screw over DLP, right?
Maybe they are,
but to get to something, right?
That's typically not their
kind of motivation.
So, their motivation is going to be
that intellectual property
of some sort.
So, that should be the objectives.
Now, if you do it right
and you either can
or can't steal
that intellectual property,
as a byproduct of what you're doing,
you're assessing that control, right?
So, to give an example,
the penetration testing team
may do a penetration test
of that DLP solution
and the infrastructure.
They may find issues and weaknesses,
but I doubt very much
they're going to find
that it's not looking at IPX,
because that's not what they're doing, right?
They're testing the infrastructure
and the solution
and the software.
But the red team will find,
potentially, the fact that
that DLP solution
isn't looking for the crown jewels,
because you've stolen it
and taken it away somewhere,
and that's the byproduct
and the knowledge they get.
Also, think about vantage point.
So, I think Rob spoke about
some different vantage points
in his presentation.
So, insider threat, opportunistic.
So, you need to be thinking about
where is it you're attacking from.
So, are you attacking
outside from the internet?
Are you trying to replicate
an insider,
so perhaps they're disgruntled
and opportunistic?
Or are we talking about
some sort of breach point?
So, assume breach,
that eventually,
we're going to get breached.
It's not impossible.
So, we're just going to start from there.
So, the issue we always have
as a red team
is we don't have unlimited budgets.
We don't have unlimited time.
So, there's always some sort of constraint.
So, we have to bear that in mind.
So, vantage point is important.
And then, of course,
the level of knowledge.
There's been a couple of blog posts
online recently
talking about
how much knowledge should red teams have
and should you just spend ages
building up your own knowledge.
And I think
there's pros and cons of each.
I think one of the biggest issues
can be when you're starting out
is you may achieve the objectives
and then someone's going to try
and discredit you, right?
Because they're going to say,
well, of course you work
in this corporation.
So, you know where we
kind of hide our skeletons
and where we keep all the gold.
So, if you take the opposite approach
by not knowing anything
and so you have to find out
all your own knowledge,
that can be more credible.
But obviously, it takes up time.
It consumes cycles.
You have to kind of work out
what the trade-off is going to be.
You also need to understand

So, like I said before,
there are going to be certain things

So, perhaps the CEO

So, you need to understand early on

that you can or can't do.
Another thing that people

So, if you send a phishing email

that's technically brand infringement, right?
So, you're breaking the law.
But we know the bad guy does this, right?
And lots of non-corporate red teams

You need to understand
if those are things
you can or can't do.
So, if you do them,

As I mentioned before,

log all the things,
cover your ass,

So, I think it's really important

This is something that I think

So, you can explain in great detail

What is the risk appetite?
